newsitem.title: GERMANY: Lamfalussy says 90 pct sure EMU will start on time.
newsitem.headline: Lamfalussy says 90 pct sure EMU will start on time.

text.p: European Monetary Institute (EMI) President Alexandre Lamfalussy was quoted on Wednesday as saying that he was 90 percent sure, but not 100 percent, that European monetary union would start on time.

Asked in an interview with Bild newspaper whether he believed the Euro would be introduced as scheduled on January 1, 1999, Lamfalussy said: "Most probably yes. But I am not as sure as financial markets. The chance is around 90 percent. But not 100 percent."

Lamfalussy also said that Germany had a good chance to meet the Maastricht Treaty's budget criterion for monetary union which states that the budget deficit must not exceed three percent of gross domestic product (GDP).

But Germany's public debt was likely to be slightly above the ceiling of 60 percent of GDP set by Maastricht, Lamfalussy said. Asked if the criteria would be softened and if they gave countries leeway, Lamfalussy said:

"There can be divergences under certain conditions for the debt reference levels of three and 60 percent - but only as an absolute exception and with a nevertheless very restrictive interpretation of the Maastricht Treaty."
Lamfalussy also said that Germany needed the Euro because a strong mark was damaging to German growth, output and the labour market.
